article.title: The Gravitational Wave Background from Massive Black Hole Binaries in Illustris: spectral features and time to detection with pulsar timing arrays

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the general trend of binary eccentricity as a function of orbital frequency for systems with an initial eccentricity (e0) greater than zero?
choices: Eccentricity remains constant across all frequencies.
Eccentricity increases with increasing orbital frequency.
Eccentricity decreases with increasing orbital frequency.
Eccentricity oscillates with increasing orbital frequency.

multiple_choice_question.text: Focusing on panels (c) & (d), how does the evolution of eccentricity for heavy & major (M > 109 M, µ > 0.1) binaries compare to that of the overall binary population (panels a & b)?
choices: Heavy & major binaries retain high eccentricities for longer at comparable frequencies/separations.
Heavy & major binaries reach zero eccentricity faster at comparable frequencies/separations.
Heavy & major binaries show no noticeable difference in eccentricity evolution compared to the overall population.
Heavy & major binaries exhibit a random distribution of eccentricities compared to the overall population.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the context of binary hardening timescales, what does the relatively flat portion of the curves between r ∼ 50 pc and r ∼ 2 × 10−2 pc in panel (b) indicate?
choices: Dominance of dynamical friction in the hardening process.
Dominance of loss-cone stellar scattering in the hardening process.
Dominance of viscous drag from a circumbinary disk in the hardening process.
Dominance of gravitational wave emission in the hardening process.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does increasing initial eccentricity (e0) affect the hardening timescale for binaries, particularly those with high masses (M > 109 M) and high mass ratios (µ > 0.1) as seen in panel (d)?
choices: Increasing e0 has no noticeable effect on the hardening timescale.
Increasing e0 leads to a less rapid hardening timescale.
Increasing e0 results in a more rapid hardening timescale.
Increasing e0 causes the hardening timescale to fluctuate erratically.

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the spectral turnover observed in the GWB strain spectrum (dashed lines) at low frequencies (f < 10−2 yr−1)?
choices: The redistribution of GW energy to higher harmonics due to eccentric binaries.
The attenuation of the GW signal due to environmental hardening processes.
The limited sensitivity of Pulsar Timing Arrays (PTAs) at low frequencies.
The quantization of Massive Black Hole Binaries (MBHBs) at low frequencies.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary assumption made in calculating the Semi-Analytic GWB spectrum using Equation (11)?
choices: All binaries coalesce effectively and purely due to GW emission.
Environmental hardening processes dominate the evolution of all binaries.
Eccentricity of binaries remains constant throughout their evolution.
The distribution of binaries in the Universe is discrete and stochastic.
